title: Understanding Lewis Structures
text: A Lewis structure is a diagram that shows the bonding between atoms of a molecule and the lone pairs of electrons that may exist in the molecule. It helps in predicting the shape, bond angles, and polarity of the molecule.

title: Bond Angles in Molecules
text: The bond angle is the angle formed between three atoms across at least two bonds. In a linear molecule, the bond angle is typically 180°. In a bent or angular molecule, the bond angle is less than 180°.

title: Molecular Shape
text: The shape of a molecule is determined by the number of bonding pairs and lone pairs around the central atom. For example, a molecule with two bonding pairs and no lone pairs is linear, while a molecule with two bonding pairs and one lone pair is bent.

title: Polar Bonds and Polarity
text: A polar bond is a covalent bond between two atoms where the electrons forming the bond are unequally distributed. The overall polarity of a molecule depends on both the individual polarities of the bonds and the shape of the molecule.
